I've seen several interesting takes on this chart but same conclusion that youth turnout was not particularly strong in 2022. Under the Responsible Financial Innovation Act proposed by @SenLummis and myself, the FTX bankruptcy could have been prevented, which Sen. Lummis explains here.

We urgently need a strong, comprehensive regulatory framework like this. https://twitter.com/SenLummis/status/1592212987259281408 QT @SenLummis The FTX bankruptcy wouldn‚Äôt happen under the Lummis-Gillibrand bill. Here‚Äôs why:

Consumers and investors would then be drawn to US-based services, confident in the protections afforded by regulatory oversight, including customer protection, as well as our robust justice system if fraud occurs.

A clear regulatory framework would encourage digital asset platforms to operate here in the US. And once they operate here within our proposed regulatory framework, they could establish trust and respect here and abroad.

Absent a clear regulatory framework, many digital asset services ‚Äì like FTX ‚Äì operate offshore. But regulations providing clarity to the industry and robust consumer and investor protections could incentivize them to do business in the US.

The United States is a global financial leader thanks to strong regulations that protect consumers and investors.

But our lack of a clear regulatory framework for digital assets and exchanges puts American consumers and investors at risk ‚Äì as we saw when FTX collapsed.

"When I meet with partners and allies around the world and ask why they are entering into dangerous agreements with the CCP, they tell me it is because we‚Äôre not there. But we need to be. We cannot allow the CCP and Russia to exert their malign influence over this continent.

"While the U.S. offers partnership, the PRC & Russia seek to leverage their offers of financing or security guarantees for their own political, economic, and security priorities. A perfect example of this is the CCP‚Äôs debt trap diplomacy through their belt and road initiative.

"In the last year, the U.S. has provided over a billion COVID-19 vaccines to African countries and nearly $2 billion to address unprecedented levels of food insecurity and famine in the Horn of Africa. We must also think long term about our investments in Africa.
"And I look forward to ensuring that important work continues and is reauthorized. The U.S. has a legacy and a depth of investment of which to be proud.

"For over two decades, under both Republican and Democratic administrations, the U.S. has partnered with African nations to address key challenges. Next year, we will celebrate the 20th anniversary of President Bush‚Äôs launch of PEPFAR.
